history.content:
Get the Algorithms Textbook by Papadimitriou,  Dasagupta and Vazirani. It covers most of the course material (and a good chunk of extra material) at a level that is appropriate for referencing and priming, which is what it seems you want to do. The book is simply called "Algorithms" and it is a fairly good read that isn't too technically challenging but is still fairly intuitive.

-------------

For SP18 Chiesa used the blackboard so he didn't have slides to post. Vazirani used an ipad, but I think the slides were posted on piazza or something - not the website. That said, as others have recommended, the textbook is definitely the way to go (or past lectures, but they follow pretty closely to the textbook). There is one caveat, special topics towards the end. Some professors put more emphasis here than others, but generally it's primality testing, hashing, streaming, quantum computing, and multiplicative updates. Here are a few useful notes from this semester:

Streaming: 

http://courses.cms.caltech.edu/cs139/notes/lecture01.pdf

MWU: 

https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs170/fa16/MWUCS170.pdf

https://www.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs.cmu.edu/academic/class/15859-f11/www/notes/lecture16.pdf

http://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~satishr/cs270/sp17/rough-notes/Lecture4/umesh-experts-lecture.pdf

The other topics were pretty well covered in lecture.

Get the Algorithms Textbook by Papadimitriou,  Dasagupta and Vazirani. It covers most of the course material (and a good chunk of extra material) at a level that is appropriate for referencing and priming, which is what it seems you want to do. The book is simply called "Algorithms" and it is a fairly good read that isn't too technically challenging but is still fairly intuitive.

children.subject: Hi OP, I'm studying for 170 over the summer to prepare for the fall term as well. If you'd like to study together (remotely, I imagine), let me know!

history.content: Hello, I will be taking CS 170 in the fall and wanted to start going over some of the notes before the semester started. However, I checked the Spring 2018 website, and even the Fall 2017 website, and was disappointed to see that the posted resources seemed to be few (from what I saw, there weren't any links for lecture notes/slides). Am I checking in the wrong place? Where would I be able to find the lecture notes/ or relevant material? Thank you!
history.subject: CS170 Course Notes
